Integral of a simple function whose codomain is `ℝ≥0∞`.

type: {α : Type u_1} → {_m : MeasurableSpace α} → MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc α ENNReal → MeasureTheory.Measure α → ENNReal
name: MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc.lintegral
docString: Integral of a simple function whose codomain is `ℝ≥0∞`.

If for a measurable function $f$ and a sequence of sets $a\_i$ with finite measures, the average of $|f(y) - c|$ over $a\_i$ converges to $0$, and for each $g\_i$ supported in $a\_i$ with integral $1$ and supremum bounded by $K/\mu(a\_i)$, then $\lim \int g\_i(y) f(y) d\mu = c$.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {m0 : MeasurableSpace α} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E]
  [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} {ι : Type u_4} {a : ι → Set α} {l : Filter ι} {f : α → E}
  {c : E} {g : ι → α → ℝ} (K : ℝ),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ⨍ (y : α) in a i, ‖f y - c‖ ∂μ) l (nhds 0) →
    (∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f (a i) μ) →
      Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ∫ (y : α), g i y ∂μ) l (nhds 1) →
        (∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, Function.support (g i) ⊆ a i) →
          (∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, ∀ (x : α), |g i x| ≤ K / (↑↑μ (a i)).toReal) →
            Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ∫ (y : α), g i y • f y ∂μ) l (nhds c)
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_integral_smul_of_tendsto_average_norm_sub
docString: If for a measurable function $f$ and a sequence of sets $a\_i$ with finite measures, the average of $|f(y) - c|$ over $a\_i$ converges to $0$, and for each $g\_i$ supported in $a\_i$ with integral $1$ and supremum bounded by $K/\mu(a\_i)$, then $\lim \int g\_i(y) f(y) d\mu = c$.

This is a statement of Cauchy's Mean Value Theorem in the context of real-valued functions. It states that given two functions `f` and `g` which are continuous on a closed interval `[a, b]` and differentiable on the open interval `(a, b)`, there exists a point `c` in the open interval `(a, b)` such that the ratio of the differences of `f` and `g` at the endpoints of the interval, i.e. `(g b - g a) / (f b - f a)`, equals the ratio of their derivatives at the point `c`, that is `(g' c) / (f' c)`. Here, `f'` and `g'` denote the derivatives of `f` and `g` respectively. The theorem essentially states that at some point in `(a, b)`, the rates of change of the two functions are proportional to the overall rate of change over the interval.

type:
∀ (f f' : ℝ → ℝ) {a b : ℝ},
  a < b →
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) →
      (∀ x ∈ Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) →
        ∀ (g g' : ℝ → ℝ),
          ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) →
            (∀ x ∈ Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivAt g (g' x) x) → ∃ c ∈ Set.Ioo a b, (g b - g a) * f' c = (f b - f a) * g' c
name: exists_ratio_hasDerivAt_eq_ratio_slope
docString: This is a statement of Cauchy's Mean Value Theorem in the context of real-valued functions. It states that given two functions `f` and `g` which are continuous on a closed interval `[a, b]` and differentiable on the open interval `(a, b)`, there exists a point `c` in the open interval `(a, b)` such that the ratio of the differences of `f` and `g` at the endpoints of the interval, i.e. `(g b - g a) / (f b - f a)`, equals the ratio of their derivatives at the point `c`, that is `(g' c) / (f' c)`. Here, `f'` and `g'` denote the derivatives of `f` and `g` respectively. The theorem essentially states that at some point in `(a, b)`, the rates of change of the two functions are proportional to the overall rate of change over the interval.

If the average of a function `f` along a sequence of sets `aₙ` converges to `c` (more precisely,
we require that `⨍ y in a i, ‖f y - c‖ ∂μ` tends to `0`), then the integral of `gₙ • f` also tends
to `c` if `gₙ` is supported in `aₙ`, has integral converging to one and supremum at most `K / μ aₙ`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {m0 : MeasurableSpace α} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E]
  [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} {ι : Type u_4} {a : ι → Set α} {l : Filter ι} {f : α → E}
  {c : E} {g : ι → α → ℝ} (K : ℝ),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ⨍ (y : α) in a i, ‖f y - c‖ ∂μ) l (nhds 0) →
    (∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f (a i)) →
      Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ∫ (y : α), g i y ∂μ) l (nhds 1) →
        (∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, Function.support (g i) ⊆ a i) →
          (∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, ∀ (x : α), |g i x| ≤ K / ENNReal.toReal (↑↑μ (a i))) →
            Filter.Tendsto (fun i => ∫ (y : α), g i y • f y ∂μ) l (nhds c)
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_integral_smul_of_tendsto_average_norm_sub
docString:
If the average of a function `f` along a sequence of sets `aₙ` converges to `c` (more precisely,
we require that `⨍ y in a i, ‖f y - c‖ ∂μ` tends to `0`), then the integral of `gₙ • f` also tends
to `c` if `gₙ` is supported in `aₙ`, has integral converging to one and supremum at most `K / μ aₙ`.

For any nonempty measurable space Ω with finite, non-zero measure μ, and any function f from Ω to a normed add-commutative group E over the real numbers, the average of f is equal to the integral of its normalized version with respect to μ.

name: MeasureTheory.FiniteMeasure.average_eq_integral_normalize
docString: For any nonempty measurable space Ω with finite, non-zero measure μ, and any function f from Ω to a normed add-commutative group E over the real numbers, the average of f is equal to the integral of its normalized version with respect to μ.

This theorem states that if a function `f` is periodic with a positive period `c`, then for every value `x` we can find a `y` in the left-closed right-open interval from 0 to `c` (denoted `Ico 0 c`), such that `f(x) = f(y)`. In other words, within every period of the function, you can find a value that the function has already taken in the first instance of that period.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} {f : α → β} {c : α} [inst : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α],
  Function.Periodic f c → 0 < c → ∀ (x : α), ∃ y ∈ Set.Ico 0 c, f x = f y
name: Function.Periodic.exists_mem_Ico₀
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` is periodic with a positive period `c`, then for every value `x` we can find a `y` in the left-closed right-open interval from 0 to `c` (denoted `Ico 0 c`), such that `f(x) = f(y)`. In other words, within every period of the function, you can find a value that the function has already taken in the first instance of that period.

If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints, then it has an extremum on this open interval.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X → Y} {a b : X} {l : Y},
  a < b →
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Ioo a b) →
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a (Set.Ioi a)) (nhds l) →
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b (Set.Iio b)) (nhds l) → ∃ c ∈ Set.Ioo a b, IsExtrOn f (Set.Ioo a b) c
name: exists_isExtrOn_Ioo_of_tendsto
docString:
If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints, then it has an extremum on this open interval.

A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
has a local extremum at some point of the corresponding open interval.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X → Y} {a b : X},
  a < b → ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) → f a = f b → ∃ c ∈ Set.Ioo a b, IsLocalExtr f c
name: exists_isLocalExtr_Ioo
docString:
A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
has a local extremum at some point of the corresponding open interval.

A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
takes either its maximum or its minimum value at a point in the interior of the interval.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X → Y} {a b : X},
  a < b → ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) → f a = f b → ∃ c ∈ Set.Ioo a b, IsExtrOn f (Set.Icc a b) c
name: exists_Ioo_extr_on_Icc
docString:
A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b`
takes either its maximum or its minimum value at a point in the interior of the interval.

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `a` from the right or from the left,
then `u ↦ ∫ x in u..b, f x` has right (resp., left) derivative `-c` at `a`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ℝ → E} {c : E}
  {a b : ℝ},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b →
    ∀ {s t : Set ℝ} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter a (nhdsWithin a s) (nhdsWithin a t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin a t) →
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a t ⊓ MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) →
          HasDerivWithinAt (fun u => ∫ (x : ℝ) in u..b, f x) (-c) s a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_hasDerivWithinAt_of_tendsto_ae_left
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `a` from the right or from the left,
then `u ↦ ∫ x in u..b, f x` has right (resp., left) derivative `-c` at `a`.

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left,
then `u ↦ ∫ x in a..u, f x` has right (resp., left) derivative `c` at `b`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ℝ → E} {c : E}
  {a b : ℝ},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b →
    ∀ {s t : Set ℝ} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter b (nhdsWithin b s) (nhdsWithin b t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin b t) →
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b t ⊓ MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) →
          HasDerivWithinAt (fun u => ∫ (x : ℝ) in a..u, f x) c s b
name: intervalIntegral.integral_hasDerivWithinAt_of_tendsto_ae_right
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left,
then `u ↦ ∫ x in a..u, f x` has right (resp., left) derivative `c` at `b`.

If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints,
then it has a local extremum on this open interval.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X → Y} {a b : X} {l : Y},
  a < b →
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Ioo a b) →
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a (Set.Ioi a)) (nhds l) →
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b (Set.Iio b)) (nhds l) → ∃ c ∈ Set.Ioo a b, IsLocalExtr f c
name: exists_isLocalExtr_Ioo_of_tendsto
docString:
If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints,
then it has a local extremum on this open interval.

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u ↦ ∫ x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ℝ → E} {c : E}
  {a b : ℝ},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b →
    ∀ {s t : Set ℝ} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter b (nhdsWithin b s) (nhdsWithin b t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin b t) →
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b t ⊓ MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) →
          autoParam (UniqueDiffWithinAt ℝ s b) _auto✝ → derivWithin (fun u => ∫ (x : ℝ) in a..u, f x) s b = c
name: intervalIntegral.derivWithin_integral_of_tendsto_ae_right
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u ↦ ∫ x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

For any function `f : α → ℝ≥0∞`, there exists a measurable function `g ≤ f` with the same
integral.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace α} (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α) (f : α → ENNReal),
  ∃ g, Measurable g ∧ g ≤ f ∧ ∫⁻ (a : α), f a ∂μ = ∫⁻ (a : α), g a ∂μ
name: MeasureTheory.exists_measurable_le_lintegral_eq
docString:
For any function `f : α → ℝ≥0∞`, there exists a measurable function `g ≤ f` with the same
integral.

An infinitely smooth function `f : ℝ → ℝ` such that `f x = 0` for `x ≤ 0`,
`f x = 1` for `1 ≤ x`, and `0 < f x < 1` for `0 < x < 1`.

type: ℝ → ℝ
name: Real.smoothTransition
docString:
An infinitely smooth function `f : ℝ → ℝ` such that `f x = 0` for `x ≤ 0`,
`f x = 1` for `1 ≤ x`, and `0 < f x < 1` for `0 < x < 1`.

A continuous function `f` is locally integrable with respect to any locally finite measure.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X]
  [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.IsLocallyFiniteMeasure μ] [inst_5 : SecondCountableTopologyEither X E],
  Continuous f → MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f
name: Continuous.locallyIntegrable
docString: A continuous function `f` is locally integrable with respect to any locally finite measure.

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `a` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u ↦ ∫ x in u..b, f x` at `a` equals `-c`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ℝ → E} {c : E}
  {a b : ℝ},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b →
    ∀ {s t : Set ℝ} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter a (nhdsWithin a s) (nhdsWithin a t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin a t) →
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a t ⊓ MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) →
          autoParam (UniqueDiffWithinAt ℝ s a) _auto✝ → derivWithin (fun u => ∫ (x : ℝ) in u..b, f x) s a = -c
name: intervalIntegral.derivWithin_integral_of_tendsto_ae_left
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `a` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u ↦ ∫ x in u..b, f x` at `a` equals `-c`.

All values of a function `f ∈ stdSimplex 𝕜 ι` belong to `[0, 1]`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {ι : Type u_5} [inst : LinearOrderedField R] [inst_1 : Fintype ι] {f : ι → R},
  f ∈ stdSimplex R ι → ∀ (x : ι), f x ∈ Set.Icc 0 1
name: mem_Icc_of_mem_stdSimplex
docString: All values of a function `f ∈ stdSimplex 𝕜 ι` belong to `[0, 1]`.

A constant function is uniformly integrable.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} {ι : Type u_3} {m : MeasurableSpace α} (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α)
  [inst : NormedAddCommGroup β] {p : ENNReal} {g : α → β},
  1 ≤ p → p ≠ ⊤ → MeasureTheory.Memℒp g p → MeasureTheory.UnifIntegrable (fun x => g) p μ
name: MeasureTheory.unifIntegrable_const
docString: A constant function is uniformly integrable.

If `f` is `ℝ`-valued and integrable, then for any `c > 0` the set `{x | f x ≥ c}` has finite
measure.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace α} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} {f : α → ℝ},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f → ∀ {ε : ℝ}, 0 < ε → ↑↑μ {a | ε ≤ f a} < ⊤
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.measure_ge_lt_top
docString:
If `f` is `ℝ`-valued and integrable, then for any `c > 0` the set `{x | f x ≥ c}` has finite
measure.

A differentiable function maps sets of measure zero to sets of measure zero.

name: MeasureTheory.addHaar_image_eq_zero_of_differentiableOn_of_addHaar_eq_zero
docString: A differentiable function maps sets of measure zero to sets of measure zero.

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely at `b`, then the derivative of `u ↦ ∫ x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : ℝ → E} {c : E}
  {a b : ℝ},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b →
    StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhds b) →
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhds b ⊓ MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) →
        deriv (fun u => ∫ (x : ℝ) in a..u, f x) b = c
name: intervalIntegral.deriv_integral_of_tendsto_ae_right
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : ℝ → E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely at `b`, then the derivative of `u ↦ ∫ x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

If `f` is `ℝ`-valued and integrable, then for any `c > 0` the set `{x | f x > c}` has finite
measure.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace α} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} {f : α → ℝ},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f → ∀ {ε : ℝ}, 0 < ε → ↑↑μ {a | ε < f a} < ⊤
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.measure_gt_lt_top
docString:
If `f` is `ℝ`-valued and integrable, then for any `c > 0` the set `{x | f x > c}` has finite
measure.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {f : ℂ → E},
  DiffContOnCl ℂ f {z | 0 < z.re} →
    (∃ c < 2,
        ∃ B, f =O[Bornology.cobounded ℂ ⊓ Filter.principal {z | 0 < z.re}] fun z => Real.exp (B * Complex.abs z ^ c)) →
      (Asymptotics.SuperpolynomialDecay Filter.atTop Real.exp fun x => ‖f ↑x‖) →
        (∃ C, ∀ (x : ℝ), ‖f (↑x * Complex.I)‖ ≤ C) → Set.EqOn f 0 {z | 0 ≤ z.re}
name: PhragmenLindelof.eq_zero_on_right_half_plane_of_superexponential_decay
